## Data loading

```{r}
#| label: loaddata
#| echo: false
#| warning: false

# ==============================================================================
# ðŸ”§ Heat Index Panel â€” Finalized on 15th April 2025
# This panel was finalized after correcting multiple errors across state-wise
# Heat Index datasets. 
# The current version reflects the corrected, merged, and verified data.
# This panel is now ready for heat index integration and downstream analyses.
# ==============================================================================

combined_data_hi_forpanel <- readRDS(here::here("data","combined_data_hi_forpanel_allindia.rds"))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(tidyverse))

#read excel file

library(readxl)

# ==============================================================================
# ðŸ“Š GBD Dataset: CVD Outcomes (2011â€“2021) â€” Updated and Corrected Version
#
# This dataset contains the most recent Global Burden of Disease (GBD) estimates
# for cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes, spanning the years 1990 to 2021.
# For our analysis, we focus on the period from **2011 to 2021**.
#
# The data are disaggregated by:
#   - Sex
#   - Age group
#   - Outcome type: prevalence, incidence, deaths, DALY, YLL, and YLD
#
# âš ï¸ Units Note:
# All outcome values are expressed **per 100,000 population**.
# Example: A value of 166 deaths corresponds to **166 deaths per 100,000 individuals**.
#
# This unit standard should be retained during all visualization and interpretation
# steps, unless explicitly scaled or transformed using population denominators.
# ==============================================================================

gbd_corrected_data <- read_excel(here::here(
  "data", "gbd-corrected-april2025","CVD_DALY_YLD_YLL_1990-2021_per100k.xlsx"
))

library(tidyverse)
gbd_corrected_data_yrsOfInterest <- gbd_corrected_data |> 
  filter(Year %in% 2011:2021) |> 
  dplyr::rename(State=Location)


# rename state.name as State
combined_data_hi_forpanel <- combined_data_hi_forpanel |> 
 dplyr::rename(State = state_name,
              Year = year)

# merge Heat Index data and gbd data

combined_data <- merge(
  combined_data_hi_forpanel,
  gbd_corrected_data_yrsOfInterest,
  by = c("State", "Year")
)



```

### Correlation Analysis

```{r}
#| label: correlation
#| echo: true
#| results: hide
# Correlation analysis
combined_data <- combined_data |> 
        rename(maximum_25=highest_25,
               maximum_975=highest_975,
               minimum_25=lowest_25,
               minimum_975=lowest_975,
               average_25=mean_25,
               average_975=mean_975,
               median_25=median_25,
               median_975=median_975) 
correlation_matrix <- cor(combined_data |> select(average_25, average_975, median_25,median_975,mode_25,mode_975,
                                                  maximum_25,maximum_975,
                                                  minimum_25,minimum_975,variation_25,variation_975), method = "pearson")
#correlation_matrix
# visualize as heatmap


# Compute a matrix of correlation p-values
p.mat <- cor_pmat(correlation_matrix)

```

```{r}
#| label: fig-corrplot
#| fig-cap: Correlation matrix for Heat Index variables
#| echo: true
#| column: page

ggcorrplot(correlation_matrix, 
           outline.color = "white",
           type = "lower",
           ggtheme = ggplot2::theme_gray,
           colors = c("#6D9EC1", "white", "#E46726"),
           lab = TRUE,
           p.mat = p.mat,
           insig = "blank")
```

@fig-corrplot *matrix shows pairwise correlations among various Heat Index metrics (average, median, mode, minimum, maximum, variation) at the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles. Only statistically significant correlations are displayed, indicating strong associations among several metrics. Based on this analysis, 97.5 percentiles of average heat index and both 2.5 and 97.5 percentiles of the variation in heat index were selected for further analysis. This is to minimize multicollinearity and retain representative variability in the downstream panel regression.*

### PAF for DALY, YLL, YLD

```{r}
#| label: pafcalc-economy
#| results: hide
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| message: false

# ==============================================================================
# ðŸ“Š GBD Dataset: CVD Outcomes (2011â€“2021) â€” Uncorrected, Absolute Counts
#
# This dataset includes uncorrected Global Burden of Disease (GBD) estimates
# for cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes from **2011 to 2021**.
#
# The data represent **total absolute counts** and are **not disaggregated**
# by sex or age group (i.e., values are aggregated for **both sexes** and **all ages**).
#
# Outcome types included:
#   - Prevalence
#   - Incidence
#   - Deaths
#   - DALY
#   - YLL
#   - YLD
#
# âš ï¸ Units Note:
# All values are **absolute numbers**, not standardized per 100,000 population.

# ==============================================================================

gbd_data_uncorrected <- read_xlsx(here::here("data","gbd-uncorrected-april2025","CVD_DALY_YLL_YLD_2011-2019_Statewise_Uncorrected.xlsx")) |> 
  janitor::clean_names()
gbd_data_uncorrected <- gbd_data_uncorrected |> 
  dplyr::rename(State=location_2,
                Year=year_7,
                CVD_DALY=daly_val,
                CVD_YLD=yld_val,
                CVD_YLL=yll_val) |> 
        filter(Year %in% 2011:2021) |> 
  dplyr::select(Year,State,CVD_DALY,CVD_YLL,CVD_YLD)


# merge Heat Index data and gbd data uncorrected

gbd_data_uncorrected_economy_forpaf <- merge(
  combined_data_hi_forpanel,
  gbd_data_uncorrected,
  by = c("State", "Year")
)

# ==============================================================================
# ðŸŽ¯ Objective: Estimating Absolute DALYs Attributable to High Average Heat Index (2021)
#
# This section calculates **absolute DALYs attributable to high average Heat Index**
# across states for the year **2021**, using the following approach:
#
#   âœ… Source: Uncorrected GBD DALY data (absolute counts) for CVD in 2021  
#   âœ… Method: Multiply state-wise DALY values by the corresponding **Population
#      Attributable Fraction (PAF)** values â€” derived from previously computed
#      **IRRs (Incidence Rate Ratios)** for high Heat Index exposure
#
# The result yields a state-wise estimate of **total cardiovascular DALYs**
# attributable to high average Heat Index in **2021** â€” an important step
# in quantifying climate-linked cardiovascular burden.
# ==============================================================================
# PAF calculation

calc_paf_from_irr <- function(irr) {
  paf <- (irr - 1) / irr
  return(paf)
}

paf_avg25_DALY <- calc_paf_from_irr(irr_avg25_DALY)
paf_avg975_DALY <- calc_paf_from_irr(irr_avg975_DALY)
paf_var25_DALY <- calc_paf_from_irr(irr_var25_DALY)
paf_var975_DALY <- calc_paf_from_irr(irr_var975_DALY)


paf_economydata_formapviz <- gbd_data_uncorrected_economy_forpaf |>
dplyr::select(State, Year, mean_25, mean_975,variation_25,variation_975,
              CVD_DALY) |>
filter(Year==2021) |> 
mutate(paf_daly_avghi25= CVD_DALY * paf_avg25_DALY,
       paf_daly_avghi25=round(paf_daly_avghi25,0),
       paf_daly_avghi975= CVD_DALY * paf_avg975_DALY,
       paf_daly_avghi975=round(paf_daly_avghi975,0),
       paf_daly_var25= CVD_DALY * paf_var25_DALY,
       paf_daly_var25=round(paf_daly_var25,0),
       paf_daly_var975= CVD_DALY * paf_var975_DALY,
       paf_daly_var975=round(paf_daly_var975,0)
       ) |> 
#dplyr::select(-CVD_Death,-avg_975) |> 
        #rename State as state
        dplyr::rename(state = State)

# ==============================================================================
# ðŸ’¾ Output: Saving Attributable DALY Estimates (2021)
#
# The final estimates of **absolute DALYs attributable to high average Heat Index**
# for each state (CVD, year 2021) are saved in two formats:
#
#   - `.csv` for easy inspection, sharing, and external use
#   - `.rds` for internal use in R workflows (preserving object structure)
#
# These files serve


write.csv(x = paf_economydata_formapviz,file = here::here(
        "output", "dalyabsolute_values_HeatIndex.csv"
),row.names = FALSE)

write_rds(x = paf_economydata_formapviz,file = here::here(
        "output", "dalyabsolute_values_HeatIndex.rds"))
```

@fig-absdaly-2021 *Cardiovascular disease (CVD) disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) attributable to high average Heat Index across Indian states in 2021. Values represent absolute DALY counts (not standardized per 100,000 population) derived from the GBD uncorrected dataset. Attributable DALYs were estimated by applying population-attributable fractions (PAFs), based on exposureâ€“response relationships, to total CVD DALYs. The figure highlights marked inter-state variation, with Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra, and West Bengal bearing the highest Heat Index-linked disease burden.*

```{r}
library(tidyverse)

india <- readRDS(here::here("data",
                            "spatial_files", 
                            "India_states.rds"))
india <- india |> 
        rename(state = NAME_1) |> 
        # recode orissa as odisha
        mutate(state = recode(state, "Orissa" = "Odisha")) |> 
# recode uttaranchal as uttarakhand
        mutate(state = recode(state, "Uttaranchal" = "Uttarakhand"))


# combine paf_data_formapviz with india based on state variable
india_paf_economy <- india |> 
  left_join(paf_economydata_formapviz, by = "state")
india_paf_economy <- india_paf_economy |> 
        mutate(centroid = st_centroid(geometry)) %>% 
  mutate(x = st_coordinates(centroid)[,1], 
         y = st_coordinates(centroid)[,2])
```

```{r}
#| label: fig-map-2021-absdaly
#| layout-ncol: 1
#| fig-cap: CVD burden attributable to high average Heat Index in Indian states
#| fig-height: 10

#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap-location: top
#| message: false
#| warning: false
#| column: screen
#| out-width: 100%
# DALY map
india_paf_economy |> 
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = paf_daly_avghi975)) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "orange", high = "midnightblue") +
  # Add paf on the states as text with x and y coordinates
  geom_text(aes(x = x, y = y, label = paf_daly_avghi975), size = 3, color = "white") +
  labs(fill = "CVD DALY",
       title = "CVD DALY attributable to high average Heat Index in Indian states",
       subtitle = "Year 2021") +
  theme_classic() +
  # Make x-axis and y-axis blank
  theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
        axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        axis.title.x = element_blank(),
        axis.title.y = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_blank())


```

@fig-map-2021-absdaly *State-wise distribution of cardiovascular disease (CVD) disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) attributable to high average Heat Index in India, 2021. Absolute DALY counts were calculated using uncorrected Global Burden of Disease (GBD) 2021 data and population-attributable fractions (PAFs) based on exposureâ€“response estimates. Values are presented as total DALYs (not standardized per 100,000 population). States are color-coded according to the magnitude of Heat Index-attributable CVD DALYs, with darker shades indicating higher burden. Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra, and West Bengal exhibited the highest values, reflecting substantial climate-linked health impacts.*


### Total economic burden attributable to high average Heat Index - 2021

```{r}
#| label: fig-totaleconburden-2021
#| echo: true
#| layout-ncol: 1
#| fig-cap: Total economic burden attributable to high average Heat Index 2021
#| fig-height: 10
#| fig-width: 14
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap-location: top
#| message: false
#| warning: false
#| column: screen
#| out-width: 100%

#  visualize total econ burden in all states by bar charts



total_daly_costcal_2021 |> 
  drop_na(totalcost_avgheatindexhigh) |>
  mutate(totalcost_avgheatindexhigh=round(totalcost_avgheatindexhigh,0)) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(State, totalcost_avgheatindexhigh), 
             y = totalcost_avgheatindexhigh)) +
  
  # Bar plot
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "darkgrey") +
  
  # Label at the tail end, just outside the bar
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0("\u20B9", round(totalcost_avgheatindexhigh / 1e7, 0), " Cr")),
            hjust = -0.1, color = "black", size = 4) +
  
  # Flip coordinates
  coord_flip(clip = "off") +  # allows text beyond plotting area
  
  # Titles and axis labels
  labs(
    title = "Total economic burden attributable to high average Heat Index, 2021",
    x = "States",
    y = "Total cost (INR)"
  ) +
  
  # y-axis in crores
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = function(x) paste0("\u20B9", x / 1e7, " Cr"),
    expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.15))  # space for tail labels
  ) +

  # Aesthetic theme
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 11),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 11),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 13),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 13),
    plot.margin = margin(10, 30, 10, 10)  # top, right, bottom, left
  )


```

@fig-totaleconburden-2021 *Total economic burden attributable to high average Heat Index across Indian states in 2021. This figure displays state-wise estimates of total economic burden (in Indian Rupees) linked to cardiovascular disease (CVD) disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) attributed to high average Heat Index. The economic burden was computed by multiplying absolute attributable DALY counts (from the GBD uncorrected dataset) with the estimated cost per DALY for 2021. The highest costs were observed in West Bengal, Maharashtra, and Tamil Nadu, reflecting both high DALY burden and high cost-per-case in these states.*

```{r}
totaleconburden_2021_hi <- total_daly_costcal_2021 |> 
  drop_na(totalcost_avgheatindexhigh) |> 
  summarise(totaleconburden = sum(totalcost_avgheatindexhigh, na.rm = TRUE))
```

::: callout-tip
### India Total Economic Burden in 2021 due to High Average Heat Index

There was a total economic burden of **`r scales::label_number(prefix = "\u20B9", scale = 1)(totaleconburden_2021_hi$totaleconburden)`** in 2021 due to high average Heat Index across Indian states. This estimate is based on the **DALY** attributable to high average Heat Index and the cost per DALY.
:::
